sub_title: Mathematics graduate looking for a tech/finance job
summary:
A pure maths research MSc graduate looking for an impactful role in the financial/tech industry where I can apply and further develop my skills.

why > how
team > freelance 
experimentation >= implementation
growth >= execution

strengths:
- problem solving skills and an analytical mind set 
- presenting technical concepts in simpler language
- efficiently reading academic papers and implementing prototypes

work flow:
1. google it
2. read what you googled
3. admit you were wrong
4. go to 1.

awards.title: JP Morgan Chase Code for Good Hackathon (winning team)
awards.description: Being part of this 24-hour non-stop programming competition to prototype solutions for the UK based charity Age UK honed my skill to think on my feet, implement software solutions and present them to a non-technical audience. Our task was to handle a large influx of volunteers contacting the charity following their viral media campaign. We developed an app to handle processing and selection of volunteers and an algorithm for matching volunteers with elderly citizens who are seeking to combat their loneliness through a regular interaction over the phone. The app protects privacy of the volunteer and the elderly person by matching them based on sufficient distance between their addresses and re-routing the calls through a third party, thereby hiding their phone numbers from each other.  My main input for this project was assessing the feasibility of solutions via statistical means and figuring out how the different modules in our code will fit together. I presented our project in front of an audience of 300+ people comprised of investors, charity representatives and competing teams.

awards.title: Merit Based Scholarship for International Exchange
awards.description: An award of 1000£ to help with travel and study expenses in Singapore awarded by University of Glasgow.

projects.title: Gelfand-Tsetlin Polytope in Representation Theory
projects.description: This project introduces a master's level topic to an undergraduate. I perfected my ability to synthesise results from different sources into a self contained piece of mathematics, guiding the reader with intuitive explanations and examples along the way. An important skill I acquired is typesetting in the scientific publishing software Tex. I have come to realise that presentation is often as important as content.

contributors.headline: Mathematics graduate looking for a tech/finance job

projects.title: Linear Representations of Finite Groups
projects.description: This summer study project helped me develop my ability to engage with higher level mathematics independently. Suggested by Dr Uli Kraehmer, the purpose was to reach Artin's theorem and Brauer's theorem on induced characters in the classical Linear Representations of Finite Groups by Jean-Pierre Serre. I gave a 20 minute talk, motivating the major results, focusing on connections with other areas of mathematics.

contributors.headline: Mathematics graduate looking for a tech/finance job

projects.title: p-adic Numbers and their implementation in Sage
projects.description:
An abstract of the talk I gave at the end of this independent study project supervised by Dr Michiel Kosters:
In 1897, Kurt Hensel introduced the field of p-adic numbers
in an effort to apply techniques from analysis to number theory. The
field, Q_p, can be obtained, for each prime p, by completing the
rationals with respect to a non-archimedean metric induced by the so
called p-adic norm. Under this metric, the distance of two rationals
is p^(-n), where n is the highest power of p that divides the
numerator of their difference. In this talk, we review the
construction of Q_p, its arithmetic and note that certain operations
can be performed more easily than in the Real number system. Next, we
cover unramified extensions of Q_p and demonstrate their
implementation in a Python based language called Sage. We conclude by
discussing some technical detail of the native parent-element
framework for introducing new algebraic structures to Sage.
